transcripts.text: My generation is often described as oversensitive.  Do you think that we're actually just emotionally aware?  A bit more compassionate?  No.  I don't think compassion is your problem at all.  Maybe we just care more about different people, different groups, making sure they're represented, making sure they're heard.  I think you're very good at... crying crocodile tears for popular causes.  I don't know that you're actually doing very much for the causes that really matter.

Sydney University is punishing four protesters who disrupted a talk by the therapist and author Bettina Arndt.  In September 2018, the Riot Squad was called to Sydney University after student protesters stopped people from entering a speech being delivered by Bettina.  Well, now the university says they're punishing four of the protesters, but... They refuse to say who's being punished or what punishment they are going to receive.  Bettina Arndt joins me live in the studio.  Bettina, good to see you.  So they're being punished.

I put in a complaint naming the four or five key organisers of the protest eight and a half months ago.  And the university has been investigating ever since, which has been amazing.  I mean, they have gone interviewed dozens of people and looked at hours of video.  But I was thinking they were just burying this.  So I was really pleased when they finally announced they're taking action against these key organisers.

Okay, let me pick you up there, though, because they've announced it today.  They've said, okay, eight-month investigation.  Now we've got the findings.  Four students are going to be punished, but we can't tell you who they are, and we can't tell you what the punishments are going to be.

And it could be just a wrap over the knuckles or a fine or through to an expulsion or suspension, which is assumed very unlikely.  But I won't find out unless those students choose to tell the press.  Of course, one of the key organisers of this event is a woman called Maddy Ford Ward, who's been in the press for all this period, saying, I organised this process, it was all due to me, and I'm sure she'll be out there telling people what happened to her because she'll now be a victim.

But in the interest of transparency, and I can, to a degree, understand the university students, mainly young people.  We all had moments of madness.  Some of them are already identified in the media.  I can maybe understand them saying, look, we're not going to hand you the names of the four.  But surely they should say this person A, B, C and D, person A received this punishment, person B that punishment, et cetera, et cetera.

Well, they're saying they won't name them because I did a YouTube video naming them in September.  Of course you did.  Of course I did.  And they said these kids got abused as a result of that.  I thought that was pretty funny.  When in fact they're now being, which is good, they're being reprimanded, they're being punished in some way for totally abusing all my audience and being really vicious and actually physically violent towards them on the night of the event.  And they objected to the fact they got some abuse on YouTube as a result of me naming them.  But we'll see.  You complained.
All these months later, more than half a year later, you've got the result that you wanted from the university.  The university council has lodged...
They've got an investigating unit.
Yep, and they've made a finding against how many students?

Apparently, up to four students, we're not sure what the misconduct charges were, but I put in a complaint under the university's own codes of conduct, which prevent bullying and harassment of students by other students and of members of the public like me, and they filed in my favour.  they're apparently taking action, at least against the major organiser.  There's a woman called Maddie Ward who constantly, proudly goes out in the press saying she organised that protest.

Yeah, and so there is some sort of censure against her.  You don't know what it is, whether it would be a fine or some sort of probation.  But at the very least, the university investigation has found that they were acting contrary to the interests of freedom of speech and freedom of expression.

breaching the codes of conduct.  Yeah.  You know, which, of course, are codes of conduct.  The irony is it's the authoritarian left that insisted the universities regulate how students treat each other.  Yeah.  No harassment, no bullying, none of that.  And now, of course, I've managed to use these codes of conduct against them.  And these people who have been charged now are irate that I've weaponised their system.

weaponise their system.  But it's good that you can.  I mean, we're all in favour of freedom of speech.  and if they disagree with what you're saying, sure, they should be able to stand out there and chant or have placards or whatever or have another rally arguing the other point of view.  But the idea of deplatforming, as they call it, is outrageous.
And I always had a Q&A.  I said, come along, fight with me, debate with me.
Yeah, you're not shy of an argument.  Not at all.

Not at all.  But what's been hilarious this week is.  this decision was made and the mainstream media has done nothing but promote fake news about it, particularly the Sydney Morning Herald and The Age announced green light for protesters.  Yeah.  And they took one phrase in the decision where the university announced that they saw both the protest against me and my talk as a legitimate expression of free speech.

Of course, that's the statement of the obvious, isn't it?  We would all agree with that.  It's a matter of how they conduct that protest and if they're shutting you down and, as you say, breaching that code of conduct.
The university cannot say that the protest was a legitimate expression of free speech and also punish the main protest.
The idea of the protest.  But if they're punishing them, then they're obviously saying they've overstepped the mark.

Overstepped the mark.  And so their announcement was totally inconsistent.  But a lot of our media decided to promote that angle rather than to say this is a historic decision.  Because Sydney University for years have been allowing these feral activists to close down any event they disagree with.

Yeah, they've done on the Israel question, Palestinian issues, and they've done them to try and shut down the conservative politicians from Julie Bishop to my old boss, Alexander Downer.  It happens all the time.

The heads of Sydney's two leading universities have warned about growing self-censorship and attempts to shut down controversial speakers.  But do maintain there is no freedom of speech crisis on campus.  That's because if people are afraid to speak, they will not be in contravention of free speech issues.
Get up and try and defend the State of Israel in a speech at a university in Sydney.  See how you go.  Exactly.

Yeah, well, what is pretty shameful about the comments, I think it was Michael Spence who made the comments where he equated Bettina Arndt, so he takes someone on the right, so-called on the right, Bettina Arndt, who has legitimate... you know, studies that she talks about to do with the fact that there isn't the so-called rape crisis.  You can agree or disagree, but she's got the data there.  That's her putting forward a legitimate point of view because she's done the study to it.  And he equates that, Vice-Chancellor, with just the howling mob who are banging on the door and yelling, you can't talk.  And he's saying these two things both problematic and he says something about I would I don't want Bettina aren't shouting at me any more than I want the kids shouting on but that's not the point.

problem is kicking in here.  we show is that we said is that when the mob turns up and I don't mean the good mob the bad mob turns up and wants to scream and yell at you like a Bettina aren't?  they say well that's the inciting of violence Because your ideas are so toxic, your ideas are so evil, that we have to push up against them.  So the boss of the university is saying, well, if you don't have the offensive ideas, you won't have the offensive reaction.
Ergo, they're the same as they should.
Grow up.
That is just so stupid.  Look, the reality is that, and I hate saying this, but it's true, on campuses, the left don't want any other point of view.  And they make sure there isn't one.  Yep.

I see there's a piece today in the Sydney Morning Herald where the university vice-chancellor you mentioned there, Michael Spence, he does acknowledge there is a problem with people having to self-censor at the university.  But then he says some frankly absurd and self-serving things that I think no one with an IQ above room temperature could understand.  possibly except uncritically.  He says, and I quote, the conservatives are as bad as the progressives and the progressives are as bad as the conservatives.  The problem is not that speech is restricted in the old fashioned says.  The problem actually is that speech is not civil.  The notion that the left has gone crazy and nobody can talk.  I don't identify that.  I think the left has gone crazy and the right has gone crazy.  Sorry, Mr.  Spence, but this isn't a both sides argument.  When is the last time that conservative students blockaded and physically intimidated people wanting to hear a progressive speaker?  When is the last time the riot squad had to be called because of the activism of conservative students protesting a leftist speaker?  The radical leftists are on your staff as well.  Let's not forget that.  So it's a little rich to pretend this is just an issue about civility.
Absolutely.
I mean, this is free speech issues.  And what's your response, Bettina, to the Vice-Chancellor?

Oh, look, it's absolutely crazy.  I mean, feminists can give talks on anything they like and you never see the Liberal Club or the Conservative Club trying to shut them down.  I mean, all manner of issues, left-wing issues, get discussed at university with no protest whatsoever.  It's all one way.  And the other key issue in this is the fact that Universities like Sydney are charging security fees.  We had to pay over $500 in security charges to pay for security officers that couldn't even protect us.  And when we asked for that money to be refunded, the Vice Chancellor said, no, they did their job, which is pretty funny, really.  I mean, it just blows me away that this vice chancellor of what was once a really important university is kowtowing to the feminists, seeking to deny the safety of his campus by pretending his campus is crawling with rapists.  and presenting me as some controversial speaker when, in fact, what I'm doing is telling the truth, which is that our campuses are very safe places for most young women, as we all know.  I mean, we've never had so many young women lining up to go to university.  60% of graduates are female.  Everybody, you know, families everywhere don't hesitate to send their girls along to uni, do they?  Well, as if they're crawling with rapists.  Everybody knows that's a lie.  So what in the hell is this man doing?  pretending there's a problem with his campus and rapists?  It just doesn't make sense.

Well, exactly.  I mean, for those who don't know, you were arguing, the whole point of your speaking to her, you were arguing that there is no rape crisis at Australian universities.  I would hardly think that's a highly controversial subject, given that, you know, the junk research that claimed that has been comprehensively debunked.  And You're right.  It's strange that you've got university vice chancellors who want to argue, no, our universities are cesspits of sexism and rape culture.

And what's really dangerous, the reason they're doing this, there's enormous pressure from the feminists to get universities involved in adjudicating rape on campus.  And Sydney University just introduced regulations to do that last year, as have a number of other universities.  And this is really dangerous.  This is about... hijacking criminal law, you know, rave accusations are now going to be adjudicated by some hotchpotch committee on campus using lower stands of proof without us having any ability to supervise what is going on there.  I've already interviewed two young men, interviewed on YouTube, two young men who've been accused by that sort of committee, one at Adelaide and one at UWA, and I'm hearing from students across Australia where this is happening.  And that's why I'm speaking on campuses.  This is a really dangerous move.  And the universities are complicit in this hijacking of our criminal law.  And someone has to speak out about this.  Thanks everybody for supporting me on my YouTube channel.  I've got growing numbers of subscribers, which is really exciting.  If you'd like to support me financially, go to my donate page on my website.  Thanks a lot.
